There is this Bisphenol A (BPA) issue in plastics also used for food packaging. BPA is said to mimic the structure and function of the hormone estrogen. Due to its estrogen-like shape, BPA can bind to estrogen receptors and influence bodily processes, such as growth, cell repair, fetal development, energy levels, and reproduction. In addition, BPA may also interact with other hormone receptors, such as those for your thyroid, thus altering their function. Your body is sensitive to changes in hormone levels, which is the reason why BPA’s ability to mimic estrogen is believed to affect your health. SOURCE: https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/what-is-bpa#risk

This issue is complex. I'm not saying nothing said in the video isn't true but clearly it's agenda driven propaganda to sell a book, call for climate activism and veganism.

The plastic portion is way, way overblown. It's obviously coming from an anti-plastic movement bias, and the meat part is obviously coming from a vegan or vegetarian agenda. Testosterone has an enzyme that converts over to DHT (dihydrotestosterone) which is very important during puberty for genital growth in men. There are many ways to go by raising your testosterone naturally. Yes, eating healthier foods is always a good idea, and avoiding plastic materials whilst cooking these foods should also be a must. But, studies show that one of the best forms in raising levels of testosterone is actually from physical therapy.

For example things like lifting weights, compound/resistance training can drastically increase your testosterone over time, followed by a healthy diet of course. Another way you can go about this, is by seeing a doctor; getting tested and seeing what your levels are and explain your situation and have them prescribe to you HRT or (Hormone Replacement Therapy). They should give a certain dosage to take every two weeks, depending how high you desire your test levels to be.

I personally feel this video did not dive into how testosterone is broken down properly, and how they function in with your pre-existing hormones.

Just want to have a quick rant about the phthalates in soaps and other personal care products. There are many many types of phthalates, but according to FDA review, practically the only one used in personal care products anymore is one called DEP. Extensive research has shown that DEP is safe for humans in the levels currently used in these products. However, when cosmetics companies get pressured by consumers to go phthalate-free, they may get rid of DEP and replace it with another ingredient that isn't as extensively studied, and so for all we know might actually be more harmful than DEP. I think it is your duty as an educational channel to not make generalizations like the one in this video, that may end up contributing to issues like this.

And if you've read this far, I also want you to know that parabens as preservatives in skincare is actually fine, and the threat of bacteria in poorly-preserved products is much riskier than the insubstantial amount of evidence there is against parabens, and also that the tiny amount of sunscreen filters that our skin absorbs is not risky compared to the huge cancer-causing danger of UV rays. the industrial revolution and its consequences

Did we get data on the leeching rate and concentrations in EDC-included-packaging packaged contents? Do we know the vectors of absorption in surface absorbed contact and/or ingested contents?

So far I'm hearing how the packaging includes the EDCs, but then we jump to studies about EDC impacts after introduction to the body. This leaves out the counter-claim that things like the phthalates are too tightly bound in the chemistry of the packaging at normal temperatures. If they are tightly chemically bonded then they would not leech, or leech at such low levels as to not matter, even if the quantities that matter are themselves very low. Anything below a line that matters is below a line of concern.

In order to point to plastic packaging or utensils as a source of ingested EDCs you need to show the mechanisms that 1) get the EDCs out of the plastics into the contents, 2) the concentrations of these transfers, 3) the length of time or number of repeated ingestions, all to get to "in a given period of time the average human ingests n quantities of EDCs." Then we can talk about the likelihood and level of impacts from that vector.

Certainly, those working in industrial processes that include phthalates will be exposed to the chemicals in a less contained form. They do not represent the risk of the general population. They are exposed to a particular situation that is known to have higher risk. What might matter there is improved safety measures or, better, new chemical products that don't use these known-harmful products.

For the general population, we live immersed in a modern, chemically-laden society with many many types of exposure that might be additive, leading to what looks like the impact of one thing, but might actually be a compound impact from many.

Show us the path and the mechanisms that the get the EDCs from plastic to human, and in what concentrations over what time, and what concentrations might build up in what tissues for how long in the body, so that we can then look to the levels we know cause harm. That's the smoking gun, and it's not included here when you jump from "plastics have these" to "and this is what they do to our bodies." You gotta prove the between, otherwise it's just correlation.

And I expect there to be some level of leeching, and some amount of subsequent ingestion, but like so many things it's the discrete quantity and the quantities over time that matter. It may be the difference between 1/5 ounce of whiskey and a 5th of whiskey. One doesn't matter much, the other matters a great deal.

The inclusion of avoid red meat or meat is such an under handed approach. I understand that you are probably reporting this from the book, but you also need to do your research. There are NO studies that directly link red meat or even nitrates (yes in large amounts fed to rats!) to low sperm count and no mechanism to explain it neither. All of them are from epidemiological studies and with both healthy user bias and weak RR and confounding factors including what those people actually ate together with the bacon, sausages and red meat.. in a burger, pizza, with lots of refined carbs and sugary sauces topped with beer and coke perhaps.

I have no arguments with the plastics and other chemical sources, but if we still think about it, what are we eating differently over the past 100 years? More refined carbs and refined sugars, lower fat, more processed plant foods, more ultra processed foods and more vegetable seeds oils. Hmmm.. I wonder why sperm count drops over the years. As to endocrine disruptors phytoestrogens is one of them and they are in soy products. True, normal consumption of soy product should have not great impact, but what if they are refined and packed into ultra processed foods and vegan products? What are we not talking about plant toxicity and blaming everything on meat with no strong evidences?

Furthermore, there are anecdotal evidences within keto + carnivore community of better sexual health after remove vegetable seeds oil and carbs/sugars and for some, plants entirely. How do you square that with avoiding red meat? Of course this is not scientific only because no big food or big pharma will ever pay to have such research done, that it why we cannot find such studies yet. However this seems to suggest the low testosterone and sperm count could be related to elevated insulin and high glucose that is promoted to the general public as healthy diet.

Culinary student here. Not going to dispute the science as I havent looked into it much myself yet but I thought you should know... that section about meats and nitrites and nitrates if you dont know what they are basically they help preserve things, nitrites are used for short term curing and preserving alongside salt and sugar and nitrates may be mixed in as over time it will degrade into nitrites. These sorts of things are often used in cured products or those meat products that are ready to consume and may include; meats in a casing like sausage and pepperoni, deli meats, and other cured and/or smoked products that may or may not have been aged. In theory they should be labeled on the package to some degree or you can ask the local butcher what they use in their sausages, overall, from what I have been taught they arent really a huge health issue, like not gonna give you a heart attack WHEN CONSUMED IN REASONABLE AMOUNTS. If you are eating 3 sticks of pepperoni and countless other high salt/sugar/fat foods I'm sure you bound to have some issues.

The only reason that will motivate people to really CARE about Global Warming and Climate Change.

This is a debate though. Should we as individuals be held accountable for what we put into our bodies or should corporations and governments be held responsible. Because if governments and corporations are held responsible for using plastics that lower sperm counts, then they should also be held accountable for the fast food they’re selling us and the pesticides they’re using and the pollution they’re generating and the addictions they’ve given us to caffeine and alcohol and and and. I mean yeah, I suppose they are to blame at least somewhat for the ills of the world, so yes we should hold them accountable. But at the same time, at what point do we just decide to treat ourselves better? At what point does it come down to us to take control of our health even if we’re given the option not to?

But to be fair, it’s not like we really have a choice in this instance. I mean what food isn’t packaged at some point? Which phones or toys or whatever you buy doesn’t contain some kind of plastic? And if companies decide to make that choice available, you know it will be more expensive. So will that choice be available to the poor? No, it won’t.

But if we want everyone to have access to this stuff, then we have to make everything available to everyone and then there’s no economic class stratification and there’s no reason for anyone to do anything...

Maybe on subjects concerning health, we can socialize things a bit more, although you could argue that everything relates to people’s health so to avoid going full communism, you’d have to draw a line somewhere. But yeah, maybe the health industry shouldn’t be an industry. Maybe our tax money should be our health insurance and we’d just incentivize research by outsourcing it to private industries. But maybe not. Will there be any edge to our research capacity and speed if there’s no competition? I don’t know, but probably not. But at the same time, maybe everyone would be able to take advantage of the healthcare we can provide now. There wouldn’t be any variation in how healthcare was provided, but at least everyone would get some of it.

My point is that it’s complicated. I’m not sure what the most effective way to treat this problem and any other problem facing our society. All I’m saying is that protesting and giving this problem to the government to handle isn’t necessarily the best option. It’s an option, but it might not be the best one.
